awd_titl_txt: Net.Create: Using Network Analysis to Support Digital Humanities in Large History Classrooms
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an EAGER award to use Network Analysis to Support Digital Humanities Learning in Large History Classrooms. It is an innovative approach to network analysis that brings simultaneous multi-user predictive network data entry and live visualization into university history classrooms to support pedagogy and learning. The network tool is called Net.Create and it will provide an easy-to use interface and curricular materials that are designed from the ground up to be successfully implemented in a lecture classroom. Net.Create supports the collaborative generation of data as a method of interpreting evidence from multiple historical texts and then using network analysis to understand the complexity of historical interactions. Net.Create will also give practical guidance for how instructors in a variety of disciplines with similar complex interactions can adapt network visualization and analysis skills, typically the focus of STEM disciplines, to support students as they engage with humanities and social science learning.

Network analysis is an increasingly popular and powerful computational tool for the analysis of large data sets. Digital historians have used these tools to represent and analyze historical contexts because they support scholars in looking at a broad range of connections between people, places, and events. While humanities pedagogues are optimistic that these capabilities also provide unique opportunities for supporting students in learning history, available tools do not support easy integration into humanities classrooms, and there is not yet empirical or theoretical support for how this might be accomplished effectively. As part of this integration, Net.Create aims to support novice history learners in recognizing how historical practices are grounded in argumentation rather than in single authoritative accounts by scaffolding students in creating and refining visualizations of historical corpora, allowing them to see these rich contexts, and then challenging them to develop and defend historical argument using these visualizations. Analysis will explore how the Net.Create tool and curricular activities contribute to students' historical practices and to student understanding of network analysis approaches, and whether these network-analysis practices result in new historical learning, retention, and understanding. The design of Net.Create is intended to support students in a wide range of contexts in engaging in challenging historical practices, and in appreciating how these practices are grounded in constructing arguments using evidence from the past. These approaches generalize beyond the 200 students of this initial pilot to students across the country via freely available tools, and across disciplines through an easy customization process. Net.Create and the associated curriculum also provide a unique opportunity to teach students to use humanities classrooms to learn cutting-edge digital approaches to scholarship which can apply across disciplinary boundaries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Net.Create project aims to bring the power of network analysis into university history classrooms to support pedagogy and learning. Network analysis is increasingly seen as a powerful computational tool for making sense of big data sets that seek to describe the large network of interdependencies created by the overlap of many individual relationships between pairs of entities. Digital-humanities scholars leverage network analysis in their scholarship to identify broad-reaching patterns that are otherwise challenging to see in large collections of texts, which can span both time and space.

Net.Create allows many people to identify and discuss interactions drawn from a collection of texts and simultaneously entering those interactions as network connections: nodes (or the things that are connecting) and edges (or the ways that those things connect). Just as important, Net.Create supports the entry and revision of citations and notes for each node and edge in the network, allowing students to engage with data science practices like network analysis and humanities interpretation practices like citation sourcing and source interpretation at the same time. Our initial findings suggest improvement in student understanding of rudimentary data-standardization, data-visualization, and network-analysis concepts in humanities classrooms. These skillsets may help humanities students incorporate these concepts into their program of studies in ways that are often not accessible to humanities-focused students otherwise. Net.Create's live data-viz features together with the citation and note-taking practices have supported humanities-network learning in more than 40 formal classroom activities in 20 classrooms, 5 of which were in classrooms outside of Net.Create's home institution.

We successfully released an open-source beta version of Net.Create on GitHub in Fall 2020. In Spring 2021, we completed the analysis and publication of an article in a top-tier journal (Computer Supported Collaborative Learning; 2020 impact factor 5.108) that addressed all of our primary research questions , bringing our total publications to 2 peer-review journal articles in press at the time of grant completion and 7 peer-review conference-proceeding submissions and a best-poster award at a major international network-analysis conference. We completed and published one journal publication in a top-tier journal.

Our understanding of how these software tool affordances shaped computer-supported collaboration has already shaped the research practices of 5 humanities research teams currently using Net.Create as their primary platform for humanities-network data collection in fields as broad as East Asian Religious Studies and late Roman imperial history. The simultaneous data-entry and visualization feature of Net.Create has supported more than 400 researchers in 25 asynchronous and synchronous humanities-networks workshops, most of these led by Net.Create users who were not on the NSF-supported team. We expect to see these adoption and usage patterns continue, especially with the Net.Create software fully available in open-source form on GitHub. In 2021 alone, Net.Create was in use for 4 humanities dissertations in progress and 3 faculty research projects at IU (including successful defense of a dissertation on networks of media patronage in India (https://mediastudies.as.virginia.edu/people/profile/tac6xr). The Institute for Digital Arts and Humanities at IU used Net.Create for seven professional development workshops between August 2020 and July 2021 (including an asynchronous workshop that has been attended by more than 150 people outside the IU community.

Based on formal surveys of 75 humanities researchers and in conversation with human-computer-interaction researchers, Net.Create's simultaneous data-entry and data-viz features will shape future research questions around collaborative HCI in data-science research and pedagogy. We are in the early stages of exploring how the collaborative network-data-entry and live visualization features of Net.Create will support epidemiology and social-determinants-of-health research. We have partnered with a private educational-equity foundation to use Net.Create as an exploratory tool to understand the connections and gaps in public funding programs designed to improve access to higher education in underserved populations.

Finally, we adjusted our data-collection approach to accommodate virtual learning in March 2019, near the end of the original project timeframe, an adjustment that helped us shape some of the final Net.Create tool features and activities to support virtual-classroom forms of network-analysis collaboration.
